posts.name: wyatt
posts.cooked:
working on a few offseason (personal) projects just thought it’d be fun to post progress here. the general idea may change for all of them but will keep working on them. most of these will stay in the cad phase but some will continue to be built, I’m currently working on a reaction wheel control system (research for it) for Areial vehicles (rockets and planes) I’ve had idea for a mars rover style project and some FRC based projects. lots of these will be based on Arduino control systems.

I will just post updates for all of my projects and maybe some questions.

posts.name: wyatt
wyatt
posts.cooked:
stayed up until about 1am last night getting some initial CAD work done, have a technical drawing for the v1.0 (fly/reaction wheel idek anymore) as well. Screenshot 2025-07-20 115517 861×660 38.6 KB all dimensions in mm. I know that lots of the dimensions and the part box isn’t very standard so if anyone has anything I should add or a better way to do things I’m open to suggestions. the flywheel will likely be made out of brass because it has a relatively high density and wont rust. (rust will change MOI and total weight) Screenshot 2025-07-20 010356 943×693 73.7 KB This is the motor + wheel assembly, the motor was a very simple model I made of this motor here, it has all of the holes and clearances I think are necessary. I’ve decided to cad the screws due to the weight budget and it will be good practice for my later projects. I’m going to start on the MOI math and the torques on the motor (to find current draw) to determine the batteries I will get for it, looking for around 8minutes of 100% speed run time.

posts.name: wyatt
posts.cooked:
Took a two day break and continued the motor mount CAD today, fixed some old math that was wrong in the weight budget and nearly finished final CAD. Officially under 500 grams not including airframe or wiring, the batteries will likely change as they take up 99 grams I still need weight for the wiring and airframe.

Question for today: are there any good 4s lipos that are around the 850-1200mah range that you have used before, if not are there any lightweight wires you/ your team uses?  The final question I have, are there any specific filaments your team or you have used that you really liked for any reason? Is there any reason the mounting bracket can’t be petg or pla?

posts.name: wyatt
posts.cooked:
are there any weight savings to be had with cf filaments or do they add weight? i have access to quite i few bambu printers and wondering if it’d be worth the time and effort or should i use pla/ petg.

side note: i may outsource the 3d printed mount for some onyx or something if i think it’d be worth it.

posts.name: Brandon M
posts.cooked: I am still learning filament types and when it’s best to use them. This season our team used the Bambu PPA-CF for a couple items on our bot. The one that really showed it’s worth was the herringbone gear on our wrist. It held up shockingly well and we would say it compares well to aluminum in that scenario while being lighter. It is not a cheap setup though. The roll itself is near $200 for half a spool. We used a Bambu X1E and a Creality Dryer with heat. All that is to say, the biggest downside with the CF filament is the cost in my experience.

posts.name: seg9585
posts.cooked:
Fun looking project!  You probably found some info like this in your research but as a 15 year spacecraft Guidance, Nav, and Control engineer I thought i’d share a few helpful tips from my experience:

Most space-based reaction wheels are configured in a tetrahedral (triangular) configuration for redundancy (can still exert momentum in any axis even if one fails or saturates)

Reaction control considers both secular and periodic momentum buildup to maximize time between desaturations.  In most cases a momentum bias is utilized to react to secular momentum and avoid frequent desats

To avoid the affects of viscosity and similar forces  in the reaction wheel assembly (particularly for wheels enclosed with lubricants), desats usually dont spin-down the wheel to zero.  Usually they are spun down to either a negative value (increasing momentum capacity) or slightly above zero

Balance in the wheel is so incredibly important.  Any non-uniform wear or fabrication (like something you’d get from 3D printing) causes vibration and this can be a killer for satellites and aircraft.  Even perfectly balanced wheels usually need some sort of shock absorption for the frame

Apply sensible rate limits to the reaction wheels if using it for attitude control.  At least in spacecraft, when pointing the satellite you will get your wheel’s momentum capacity back when nulling rates after a slew, but only if you didn’t saturate

If you want to expand beyond reaction wheel system, take a look at Control Moment Gyros, which can apply much larger torques thanks to the gyro’s angular momentum.  This is used on larger, heavier satellites where higher rate limits are needed.

posts.name: wyatt
posts.cooked:
Thankyou for the insight, very cool stuff. My wheel will just sit horizontally and control the roll axis of a small model rocket but may look into some kind of small dampening system (how truck cabs attach to frame with rubber pads or something similar) it would just be a little more work and because I’m only leaving around 4-8 millimeters between the outside of the wheel and the airframe it could be difficult but very interesting.

I’ve looking into building a tetrahedral style system just for fun, but want to get this first one done before that. Just because you might know, what kind of test stands would people use to hold the frame (cube sat style frame) when testing on earth lol would it be like a fft gyro style stand or something else.

posts.name: seg9585
posts.cooked:
For a personal project like this, you could likely just use rubber dampeners on the screws that mount your gyro structure to the frame, very similar to dampeners used in FPV racing drones.

IMG_6092 584×659 12.2 KB

IMG_6092 584×659 12.2 KB

IMG_6092 584×659 12.2 KB

Mounting structure like this is what I see a lot:

IMG_6091 1019×956 66.4 KB

IMG_6091 1019×956 66.4 KB

IMG_6091 1019×956 66.4 KB

In terms of a test stand, typically just fancy set of load cells will do, to measure the resultant force from the angular acceleration.  Integrate over time to get your impulse.

when I was testing my own personal reaction wheel design for a recent high altitude balloon personal project (single axis), I just strung it from a string in my house to test its ability to null rates and adjust attitude.

posts.name: wyatt
posts.cooked:
Oh that makes more sense, I was thinking about those kind of feet for it. Had the same string idea for the one axis. As far as the testing a three axis, could you test one axis at a time or do you have to test all three (tetrahedral wheel setup) I feel like you could string it and then just test each axis individually but wondering if that would work.

Thank you so much

posts.name: wyatt
posts.cooked:
the first circuit board (hopefully of many) I am making is the ‘pdp’ for my robot, I am purposefully overbuilding the heck out of it so I can build bigger things later I’ve settled on the same wago 2606-1101 found on the REV PDHs high current channels(40A) the official Wago website has them in red and black and are marked as 2606-1101/000-005 for the red one and the black one is the same but with a four instead of a five on the end. it will likely have similar screw blocks for power in found on the pdp 2.0 and those i just found m6 screw blocks on digikey. hoping to get the schematic out today and finalized. I might end up putting in an off the shelf LCD voltage monitor in it so I can have that handy at some point. if there are any files people would like to have for this project, I’m open to sharing them, they might not be standard of any kind because it is my first time using kicad well, I’ve tried before but not great.

if anyone has any resources for designing voltage step down circuits (or knows anything about them in general) it would be wonderful if you could share those. I’m thinking about using kobalt 24V 4A power tool batteries to run it, I already have a few and I figure it would be easier to half the voltage and double amp then to deal with dewalt and have to 2/3 the voltage and such.

IMO wanting to use kobalt batteries but need to half the voltage.

posts.name: wyatt
posts.cooked: What amperage step down would I be looking for, the batteries output 4amp as it and I’m looking to use two or maybe four of them.(24v 16a(would it then go to 12v 32a?)) If I step down the voltage to twelve volts does it double the amps? I’m finding out a lot online but can’t seem to make any sense of it. Any guidance here would be great. It would be a closed loop system I think because it’s not plugged into anything other than what’s in the robot. Are there any good resources on learning custom electronics like this or just general electrical engineering/pcb design.

posts.name: wyatt
posts.cooked:
Still very lost, I found a board on digikey that will step down 24v to 12v and allegedly output 40 amps, which would work with my 24v 16a input? I think it would but I’m not very good at this yet. Would this work and if so, would It work well, does anyone know of any other way to drop down voltage?

Step down converter: RPMGH12-40 Recom Power | Power Supplies - Board Mount | DigiKey
